This list highlights the best municipal bond funds from 2007 to 2016, based on each fund outperforming the Bloomberg Barclays Municipal Bond index over the last 1-, 3-, 5- and 10-year periods. Shaded cells indicate the best-of-the-best funds based on 10-year performance.All returns as of Dec. 31, 2016.View Full Special Report: Best IBD Mutual Fund AwardsView All Award-Winning Funds In Each CategoryRELATED:Best Mutual Funds: See IBD's Latest Performance Reports And Fund Manager ProfilesBest ETFs: Track The Top-Performing Exchange Traded Funds And Related News

The best mutual funds the past 10 years in U.S. taxable fixed income had a common thread: They were risk takers.IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards were given to U.S. taxable, international and municipal bond funds. Winners had to have at least $100 million in assets and beat their respective benchmarks in each of the one, three, five and 10-year periods through December 2016. Best of the best awards went to the top five benchmark beaters ranked by 10-year returns.In the domestic taxable universe, the top three performers were BTS Tactical Fixed Income A (BTFAX), Delaware Extended Duration Bond Institutional (DEEIX) and AB High Income A (AGDAX) with 10-year returns of 8.53%, 8.47% and 8.17%, respectively. In 2016 alone, they racked up 13.79%, 7.5% and 15.17% each.The $665 million BTS fund focuses not just on providing income to bond investors, but also capital appreciation. Over 85% of the fund is in high-yield bond ETFs, but it also uses defensive capital preservation strategies such as stop-loss measures to reduce downside risk. This top performer doesn't come cheap: it has a maximum load, or commission, of 5% and a 1.58% expense ratio. Its current yield is 2.8% and it has a duration, a measure of sensitivity to interest changes, of a relatively low 3.89 years.Delaware Extended Duration is much more sensitive to rate changes, having a duration of 13.4 years. That sensitivity has propped up its yield to 3.7%. The fund charges a 0.71% annual fee. Its average credit quality is BBB.As spreads have tightened significantly in the corporate bond market and interest rates are expected to rise in 2017, the key message is to "follow coupon, because coupon is going to help offset some of your price declines," said Jennifer Vail, head of fixed income research at U.S. Bank.Internationally, GMO Emerging Country Debt III (GMCDX), TCW Emerging Markets Income I (TGEIX) and Fidelity New Markets Income (FNMIX) were the winners with 8.37%, 7.89% and 7.26% 10-year average annual returns, respectively. Last year paid off well in the emerging markets as those funds brought in between 13% and 15% in returns.Fidelity's $5.2 billion New Markets Income fund mostly invests in dollar-denominated sovereign and parastatal debt of emerging market countries. Manager John Carlson, who has run the fund since June 1995, keeps about two-thirds in sovereign and quasi-sovereign debt, and allocates the rest in sources of alpha such as local currency bonds, whether corporate or government, or even equities."I tend to keep the fund in more liquid positions rather than illiquids," said Carlson. "My approach is based on the mosaic approach. I'm looking to build a picture of a sovereign country's ability and willingness to repay their debt."To achieve this goal, Carlson travels to those countries to speak with top government and corporate officials. Carlson does not use derivatives, leverage or shorting, and prefers to manage the fund in a consistent manner.Last year, Carlson successfully took advantage of very wide credit spreads in the oil-producing countries when oil prices fell to below $30 a barrel. As such, he overweighted oil bonds such as Petrobras, Petroleos De Venezuela, Argentina Republic and Russian Federation. "Those oil credits were responsible for probably a couple of 100 basis points of outperformance," he said.At the same time, he went underweight investment grade credits, such as the Philippines, China, Poland and Indonesia, where he felt spreads were too tight.Aside from the strong performance exhibited by emerging markets bond funds, global bond funds with a more broadly diversified bond portfolio also did well. GuideStone Funds Global Bond Investors (GGBFX)'s 10.91% return in 2016 got a lift from an opportunistic allocation to high yield, bank loans, convertible debt, emerging markets and U.S. investment grade financials and industrials credits."We provide a fund that has a very broad opportunity set and give the ability to our underlying subadvisors to have the flexibility and opportunity to go where there are dislocations in the market place," said Matt Peden, chief investment officer at GuideStone Capital Management. The $444 million fund is subadvised by Loomis Sayles and Western Asset Management. It carries a yield of 3.83% and a fee of 0.82%.Prudential Global Total Return A (GTRAX) looks for as many different alpha drivers as possible. The $730 million fund has a strong focus on security selection and sector allocation. "While interest-rate and currency positioning for some global funds are the primary focus, for us those are secondary activities; primary for us is bottom-up asset selection — finding a diversified set of the best risk-adjusted opportunities," said fund manager Robert Tipp.The fund benefited from high-quality structured credit such as CMBS, emerging market sovereigns and high yield corporate bonds in 2016. "It was an environment where expectations of economic growth and a relatively docile Fed backdrop was very conducive to spread contraction," Tipp noted.The fund returned 2.59% in 2016 and 5.01% for the 10 years. It yields 3.52% and has an expense ratio of 0.97%.Among nontaxable bonds, performance was quite even for the 10-year period. Top three performers are the Nuveen CA Municipal Bond (NCSPX), Ivy Municipal High Income I (WYMHX) and Delaware National High-Yield Muni Bond A (CXHYX) with 4.99%, 4.97% and 4.97%, respectively.Muni high-yield bonds did especially well in the first part of last year. But they behaved in a rather unusual fashion following the U.S. presidential election in November, underperforming corporate high yield."Despite the end-of-year performance downturn, municipal high yield is currently offering both outstanding relative value and attractive yields," noted Jim Colby, portfolio manager for municipal bonds at VanEck in a recent report. "I believe it's time to hit the "reset" button and reconsider municipal high yield."RELATED:Next ETF Leaders For Rising Interst Rates

ServiceNow (NOW) announced Chief Executive Frank Slootman will step down as of April 3, to be replaced by John Donahoe, chairman of PayPal (PYPL) and a former CEO of eBay (EBAY).Slootman will continue to serve as the chairman of ServiceNow's board.ServiceNow stock fell 4.4% to 87.75 in the stock market today, still up more than 15% in 2017 but down 7% from its all-time high of 93.97 set on Feb. 15.Donahoe was president and CEO of eBay from 2008 to 2015. EBay spun off PayPal in 2014.IBD'S TAKE: Broadcom, Western Alliance Bancorp and Primerica are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Analysts were surprised by Slootman stepping down amid intensified competition with Salesforce.com (CRM)."We are not thrilled to see Mr. Slootman moving to the chairman role," said Keith Bachman, a BMO Capital Markets analyst, in a research report. "In our view, Slootman has been the key architect, or at least a key architect, in ServiceNow's strategy of moving into new good growth opportunities beyond ITSM."Founded in 2004, ServiceNow developed software for information technology service management (ITSM), basically IT help desk tools for tracking internal company issues. ServiceNow has expanded into new markets such as human resources, customer service management and security.Slootman has been ServiceNow's CEO since 2011. He earlier headed Data Domain, which was sold to data storage networking giant EMC in 2009.ServiceNow's 2016 sales boomed 38% to $1.4 billion. ServiceNow has forecast 2017 revenue growth of 32% to $1.835 billion at the midpoint of its guidance."While we expected Slootman would not remain CEO forever, we expected more signs of succession process before an announcement like this," said Walter Pritchard, a Citigroup analyst, in a report. "We believe the company had looked at bringing in an apprentice like successor, they opted to go with an exec (Donahoe) that has managed a $20 billion business."Santa Clara, Calif.-based ServiceNow has set a goal of $4 billion in revenue by 2020."Software CEOs have a history of handing off the job at 'the top,'" added Pritchard. "We expect near-term investor sentiment will reflect concern around this, even though there are no obvious signs of peaking momentum."ServiceNow has prospered by taking away the customers of BMC Software, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), CA Technologies (CA) and others."As with any new leadership, we believe that there could be some turnover within the senior management layer as Mr. Donahoe looks to build out his team," said Mizuho Securities in a report.RELATED:Meet The 'Fastest-Growing' $1 Billion Enterprise Software FirmWill Microsoft Stymie Salesforce.com's Stock Turnaround?

Technology investors looking for high revenue growth often find their answer in software-as-a-service companies.ServiceNow (NOW) is one of the fastest-growing companies that fits that bill. ServiceNow's 2016 sales exploded 38% to $1.4 billion, and it has laid claim to being the "fastest-growing enterprise software company with more than $1 billion in revenue."It has set big goals, too. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company plans to nearly triple its revenue to $4 billion by 2020."There's not another company that produces growth at our scale like we do," Frank Slootman, ServiceNow's chief executive, said in an interview. "It's a trifecta — scale, growth and free cash flow."ServiceNow faces fierce competition, though, most notably from Salesforce.com (CRM), currently the market leader in the industry known as SaaS. Salesforce.com's 2016 sales boomed 24% to $6.7 billion, and the San Francisco-based company is on track to hit $10 billion in revenue for the current fiscal year. It's aiming to hit $20 billion after that.Salesforce.com has the higher profile, being oft-mentioned in industry merger activity, whether it involves Microsoft (MSFT), LinkedIn, Twitter (TWTR) or another company. It specializes in software that helps businesses organize and handle sales operations.But ServiceNow stock has shot up 25% in 2017, while Salesforce.com is up 18% after lagging last year.SaaS companies sell online subscriptions to software, rather than one-time licenses. SaaS providers have high customer renewal rates and book recurring revenue over the long term. Most sell into the so-called "enterprise market" — large companies, government agencies and other big customers.ServiceNow has prospered by taking away the customers of BMC Software, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), CA Technologies (CA) and other "on-premise" software providers that shifted slowly to cloud-based SaaS business models.Founded in 2004, ServiceNow developed software for information technology service management, basically IT help-desk tools for tracking internal company issues. As Salesforce.com has expanded into marketing, customer service and e-commerce, ServiceNow has made a similar push into customer-service tools, heightening the rivalry between the two.Salesforce.com has been an acquisition machine, spending more than $4.6 billion in 2016 alone to buy companies.In ServiceNow's case, though, it can hit its $4 billion target by growing "organically," meaning without big acquisitions, says Alex Zukin, a Piper Jaffray analyst."There may be opportunities for them to enhance the breadth of their offerings with (small) tuck-in acquisitions," Zukin added.ServiceNow expects to reach its $4 billion revenue goal by expanding into new markets — human resources, customer service management and security, to name a few — and by landing bigger contracts while targeting the top 2,000 global companies.ServiceNow has bought small companies like Neebula Systems, iTapp and most recently DxContinuum to acquire "talent and technology," said Slootman, who has been ServiceNow's CEO since 2011. He earlier headed Data Domain, which was sold to data storage networking giant EMC in 2009."Technology is not as useful without the talent," Slootman said. "We have the ability to sell, so I don't need to acquire revenue or customers. We can do that ourselves. We try to acquire small companies with promising technology before they go vertical and their revenue explodes, because then it's way more expensive (to acquire them)."ServiceNow still garners most revenue from service management, but the 2014 Neebula acquisition provided key technology for mapping a customers' IT infrastructure in case outages or other problems occur. That's a different market, called IT operations management. ServiceNow's 2016 purchase of ITApp provided cloud management tools.ServiceNow's operations management tools account for about 9% of subscription revenue, with that expected to grow to at least 15% by 2020.Slootman says the same software tools that automate information-technology workflows and record keeping can be applied for finance, legal, procurement and other corporate departments. Like Salesforce.com, ServiceNow is building a library of business apps that customers can download via the internet.The name of the game for many SaaS companies is building a cloud "platform" so they can sell multiple software tools to different industries.IBD'S TAKE: After a series of flat bases over the last 10 months, ServiceNow broke out last month and is staking out higher ground above the 90 level. ServiceNow is the eighth-ranked company in IBD's Computer Software-Enterprise Group. Tops on the list is Paycom Software (PAYC), which has a Composite Rating of 95 out of a possible 99."In software everyone claims to be a platform play, but in reality there are only a few that can make that claim, and ServiceNow is one of them," said Matthew Hedberg, a RBC Capital analyst in a report.Much of ServiceNow's revenue growth has come from "cross-selling." Its sales staff aims to sell more products to existing service management customers. IBM has emerged as a key partner of ServiceNow, reselling its service management and other tools. Accenture has been a marketing partner in the government market.Alex Zukin, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, says IBM looms as a "logical acquirer (of ServiceNow) over the longer term.""ServiceNow's platform would be a logical extension of IBM's cloud infrastructure," Zukin said.In mid-2016, ServiceNow was among companies listed in a score card of possible Salesforce.com acquisitions that leaked from a board of directors meeting. Pegasystems (PEGA) and Tableau Software (DATA) also were on Salesforce's wish list, but ServiceNow's market cap is much bigger at more than $15 billion.ServiceNow generates hefty free cash flow, a feat that's not common among SaaS companies, and a plus for any potential acquirers. Free cash flow rose 40% to $322 million in 2016.The company reported unadjusted earnings of 71 cents in 2016 but it's still not profitable on an adjusted basis, which includes stock-based compensation. Shares of ServiceNow ended trading Friday up 1% to 92.74, and were up another 0.5% Tuesday to close at 93.18.ServiceNow has forecast 2017 revenue growth of 32% to $1.835 billion, at the midpoint of its guidance. Billing growth has stabilized after slowing in 2015, when the company reorganized sales. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are modeling 54% earnings growth to $1.08 a share in 2017.A roadmap to ServiceNow's $4 billion revenue goal was revealed in May 2016. A month earlier, it settled patent infringement cases with BMC and HPE. Analysts expect ServiceNow to continue taking share in the service management market from BMC and others, though privately held Cherwell Software is a strong rival.As ServiceNow expands into new markets, analysts say it could run into more competition from the likes of Atlassian (TEAM), Zendesk (ZEN) and Splunk (SPLK).Zukin says that in many cases ServiceNow's management software can work alongside other tools. He says human resources, where Workday (WDAY) is a leading provider, is one example.The Salesforce rivalry, though, seems to be growing."Historically, ServiceNow's messaging has been that ServiceNow and Salesforce.com can coexist in accounts. The new message seems to be that customers are increasingly taking a 'CRM model' or 'service management' platform approach," Brian Schwartz, an Oppenheimer analyst, wrote in a recent report to clients. "In other words, we believe the two platforms will increasingly be seen as future alternatives rather than running in parallel."ServiceNow aims to leverage its database technology to provide more problem-solving tools in handling customer-service issues. Both Salesforce.com and ServiceNow are adding artificial intelligence to software. By embedding data analytics and "machine learning" into software, they aim to make it easier for customers to automate tasks.ServiceNow acquired AI startup DxContinuum in January. Slootman says he plans to utilize DxContinuum's  throughout ServiceNow's cloud platform. The tools will help customers build predictive models that make it easier to categorize incoming requests from company employees.Aside from HR, customer service and security, Slootman says SeriveNow could target other areas."The good thing about this model is we can try things, we can be opportunistic," Slootman said. "If something works, we'll do more. But we can also back out if it doesn't. There are no life-and-death bets. We can be very agile in how we move in or out of adjacent markets."RELATED:Will Microsoft Stymie Salesforce.com's Stock Turnaround?

ServiceNow's (NOW) Q4 beat-and-raise late Wednesday won at least six price-target hikes for the stock, which broke out Thursday, gapping up to a record high.ServiceNow jumped as much as 7.7% in the stock market today to a high of 92.98, ending the day at 89.48, up 3.6%.The enterprise software provider late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter non-GAAP profit and revenue that topped Wall Street views, as did its current-quarter and full-year revenue guidance.RBC Capital hiked its price target to 108 from 95, Citigroup to 107 from 95, BMO Capital Markets to 104 from 97, Mizuho to 100 from 90, FBN Securities to 110 from 105, and UBS to 101 from 93."We don't believe any other company in our high-growth universe is showing this strong growth at scale in core and such a ramp in new products," Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard said in a research report. "At the same time, the ability to continue margin ramp is also unmatched."We believe this is testament to culture of strong execution, making the right product choices and also the fortune of a benign competitive landscape."IBD'S TAKE: With Thursday's gain, ServiceNow stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base and leapt into a buy zone, climbing past a buy point of 89.89 in high volume. Learn more on ServiceNow's growth trends at IBD Stock Checkup.ServiceNow's core business is software for information technology service management, or ITSM. ServiceNow has expanded into human resources, customer service and security software.ServiceNow's push into new markets has heated up competition with Salesforce.com (CRM), which has been viewed as a possible buyer. Other rivals include CA Technologies  (CA)  and Hewlett Packard Enterprise  (HPE). ServiceNow has a new partnership with IBM (IBM)."ServiceNow is operating at a very high level as the flywheel of a true multiproduct platform company accelerates," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a report. "Billings easily beat expectations and accelerated due in part to strong large deal activity, strong cross sell and high renewal rates."ServiceNow said Q4 profit minus items rose 26% year over year to 24 cents a share, as revenue jumped 37% to $392 million. Analysts had expected EPS of 23 cents and revenue of $379 million.For the current quarter, ServiceNow forecast revenue of $406 million to $411 million, up 33% to 34%. Analysts had projected $403 million. For the year, ServiceNow forecast revenue of $1.82 to $1.85 billion vs. consensus estimates of $1.8 billion.Piper Jaffray analyst Alex Zukin maintained a neutral rating on the stock, citing its steep climb of late. ServiceNow stock is up 22% in 2017."While we believe that the company is well-positioned to execute on its goal of $4 billion in revenue in 2020, we would remain sidelined at current valuation levels pending a better entry point," Zukin said in his research report.RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPESalesforce.com Stock Rallies In 2017 As Top Software Pick

ServiceNow (NOW) reported fourth-quarter non-GAAP profit and revenue that topped views and forecast current quarter and full-year 2017 revenue above consensus estimates, sending shares in the enterprise software provider up in late trading.ServiceNow said Q4 profit minus items rose 26% to 24 cents from the year-earlier period as revenue jumped 37% to 392 million. Analysts had expected EPS of 23 cents and revenue of $379 million.For the current quarter, ServiceNow forecast revenue in a range of $406 million to $411 million, up 33% to 34%. Analysts had projected $403 million. For the full year, ServiceNow forecast revenue in a range of $1.82 to $1.85 billion vs. consensus estimates of $1.8 billion.ServiceNow stock leapt 5.6% to 91.21 in late trading in the stock market today. In the regular session, ServiceNow stock had climbed 2.8% to 86.37, breaking out of a caup-with-handle base with a buy point of 85.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix, Quanta Services and Broadcom are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping."Strength in Q4 was driven by a record 27 new deals greater than $1 million in net new annualized contract value, and 31 net new global 2000 customer wins," said Michael Scarpelli, ServiceNow's CFO, in a release.Q4 billings rose 46% to $535 million vs. consensus of $478 million.ServiceNow fell 14% in 2016, but shares have moved above their 50-day moving average in January, with a buy point of 89.89.ServiceNow's core business is software for information technology service management, or ITSM. ServiceNow has expanded into human resources, customer service and security software.ServiceNow's push into new markets has heated up competition with Salesforce.com  (CRM) which has been viewed as a possible buyer. Other rivals include CA Technologies (CA), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), and IBM  (IBM).RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPESalesforce.com Stock Rallies In 2017 As Top Software PickServiceNow Price Target Hits 100 On Earnings Beat

Cisco Systems' (CSCO) acquisition of AppDynamics for $3.7 billion sparked takeover speculation of other software companies, with shares of New Relic (NEWR) and Splunk (SPLK) both surging Wednesday.Cisco late Tuesday snapped up AppDynamics just before it was set to be the first big tech IPO — the first tech unicorn IPO — of 2017. New Relic stock rose 11% to 36.85 in the stock market today, earlier hitting 40.10, just below a record high for a company that went public in 2014 at 23.Splunk stock rose 7.6% Wednesday, hitting a nearly two-month high and rising above both its 50-day and 200-day lines for the first time since early this month.Cisco stock edged up 0.33% Wednesday.AppDynamics provides cloud-based software that measures and analyzes the performance of business critical applications."The acquisition broadens Cisco's software portfolio as Cisco attempts to diversify its revenue base with more subscription and recurring revenue," said Alex Kurtz, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, in a research report. "The traditional market for application performance management (APM) is roughly $4 billion, but analytics, the shift to cloud deployments and the consolidation of monitoring tools appears to be expanding the addressable market."Other vendors with APM exposure include Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and NetScout Systems (NTCT). We believe there is a split in the market between the next-generation players, with AppDynamics tending more toward hybrid cloud deployments and New Relic toward public cloud and digital deployments."IBD'S TAKE: Seacoast Banking, Inphi, GrubHub and NetEase are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. AppDynamics, which recently raised the target range of its IPO to $12-$14 a share from $10-$12, was expected to price Wednesday night and begin trading on Thursday. The software maker had targeted a maximum valuation of $1.7 billion.AppDynamics will operate as a unit in Cisco's IoT division.Splunk is an AppDynamics rival and some have said it's also been eyed by Cisco, Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard said in a research note. He says those rumors likely will cool after Cisco's announcement."We think Splunk and AppDynamics fight for budget in some customer projects and we expect the intensity of this would increase or decrease depending on how Cisco executes in integration and its leverage of AppDynamics offerings across broader distribution channel," Pritchard wrote. "Some had viewed Cisco as a potential acquirer of Splunk and while SPLK and AppDynamics are somewhat complementary, we expect investor sentiment around a Cisco/Splunk combination to cool."In any case, a host of software mergers could be in the offing, analysts say."We expected 2017 to be a better year for software M&A, and we certainly got off to a strong start with this transaction," RBC Capital analyst Matthew Hedberg said in a report. "In addition to AppDynamics, other market leaders in the APM space include New Relic and privately-held Dynatrace as well as challengers including CA Technologies (CA), IBM (IBM), Hewlett Packard Enterprises, BMC Software and Riverbed."Ittai Kidron, an analyst at Oppenheimer, said: "We're mixed on the Cisco acquisition's impact on New Relic. Positively, it suggests meaningful valuation upside and could put NEWR into play (potentially IBM or another legacy APM vendor). It also could create some execution distraction at AppDynamics."RELATED:Cisco Systems Nabs AppDynamics For $3.7 Billion, Just Before IPO

Analysts backpedaled Monday from a collective theory in February that cybersecurity spending would slump in 2016, while CyberArk Software (CYBR) garnered an upgrade on continued acquisition chatter.IBD's 25-company Computer Software-Security industry group toppled 7.4% and 7.2% in back-to-back sessions last month after Tableau Software (DATA) and LinkedIn (LNKD) issued gloomy guidance. Since then, however, the group has rebounded 28%."Based on conversations post-RSA, our security spending concerns have diminished," Summit Research analyst Srini Nandury wrote in a research report Monday, referring to the annual RSA cybersecurity conference this month in San Francisco, which more than 40,000 people attended.CyberArk's bread and butter -- privileged account security -- remains a top spending priority in 2016, Nandury wrote. He upgraded CyberArk stock to a buy and boosted his price target to 50 from 30.Nandury noted his upgrade is supported "with persistent chatter of CyberArk as a potential acquisition candidate, while limiting downside from current levels." Last month, rumors arose that fellow Israeli firm Check Point Software Technology (CHKP) might be eyeing CyberArk.In afternoon trading on the stock market today, CyberArk stock was up a fraction, near 39. The IBD security software group was down a fraction, hurt by a 16% plunge for NQ Mobile (NQ) stock. NQ announced Monday that a subsidiary of China's Tsinghua Holdings would not be able to proceed with a planned acquisition of NQ subsidiary FL Mobile.Enterprises are shifting some spending from endpoints to privileged account spending, where CyberArk leads, Nandury wrote. Surveys show cybersecurity spending at the forefront of chief information officers' minds driven by "state-sponsored breaches and hacker collectives.""Chief information officers understand that once hackers penetrate the perimeter, they look to hack privileged accounts (super-user and administrative accounts) to get to the data," he wrote. "Securing privileged accounts then takes on great importance."Nandury sees CyberArk hitting its 30% sales growth target as it aggressively expands headcount. Sales and marketing spending is expected to remain in the 35%-40% range, he says.But days before Nandury's upgrade, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho cut his 2017 estimates on CyberArk to take a conservative investment viewpoint. However, Ho still rates CyberArk stock at outperform.For 2017, Ho sees $1.12 earnings per share ex items vs. earlier views for $1.37. He cut pro forma operating margin to 21.2% from 26.3%, and projects 27.3% billings growth vs. earlier expectations for 33.6% growth.CyberArk's December-quarter results were impressive, considering their difficult comparison, Ho wrote in his report. He expects CyberArk to continue market share gains against CA Technologies (CA) and Dell.Like Nandury, he noted that CyberArk says it hasn't seen a drop-off in demand. A January CIO survey by Piper Jaffray shows internal access management, which includes CyberArk's crown-jewel-protecting core, as the fourth-most-important spending target for 2016.Endpoint, compliance and Web-access firewall led the survey in terms of spending priorities.

Now that most companies have reported their latest quarterly earnings, let's see which IBD Dividend Leaders show the biggest dividend growth.The top three in Monday's IBD are all tech stocks, which are known more for investing heavily in research and development than for paying out dividends. But a few older tech names have become more recent entrants to the dividend-paying universe.Cisco Systems (CSCO) tops the list with 42% long-term growth in its cash payout. The San Jose-based chipmaker, which began paying dividends in 2011, reported fiscal Q2 earnings in February that topped views. It raised its payout by 24% to 26 cents a share, or $1.04 for the full year, which works out to a 3.9% yield. That's well ahead of the S&P 500's average 2.2% payout.Cisco's annual profit gains have slowed from the company's younger years, but they remain quite steady. Its three-year Earnings Stability Factor is 1 on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile). Its three-year earnings growth rate is 5%. The stock is trading between its converged 10-week and 40-week moving average lines. It's been consolidating for nearly a year in a 26% deep, undefined pattern.Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) comes in second with a 23% dividend growth rate. The San Diego-based company, which started paying dividends in 2003, offers a quarterly payout of 48 cents a share, or $1.92 annualized, for a 3.7% yield.Qualcomm shares rose the past three weeks, after having trended mostly lower since July 2014. They're now back above the 10-week moving average but still submerged 8% below the falling 40-week line.CA (CA) has been paying dividends regularly since 1990. The New York-based enterprise software maker pays 25 cents a share on a quarterly basis, for a 3.4% annualized yield. The stock has climbed back above its 10-week and 40-week lines and is 12% off its 52-week high. Shares have been consolidating for nearly 13 months.

Biotech Dynavax Technologies (DVAX) soared Thursday, even as the market overall crashed, after its hepatitis B vaccine beat GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK) standard product in a late-stage clinical trial.Dynavax said that its vaccine, Hepislav-B, showed a 95.4% rate of peak seroprotection, in contrast with only 81.3% for Glaxo's Engerix-B. Dynavax focused especially on patients with diabetes mellitus, who don't respond well to current vaccines and treatments. In the study, the seroprotection rate for Hepislav-B was 90%, as opposed to Engerix-B's 65.1%.The study also showed that the two vaccines had similar safety profiles. A number of adverse events occurred in both arms, mostly autoimmune-related, but Dynavax said that they were not related to vaccinations.Dynavax said that it will file for U.S. approval of Hepislav-B by the end of this quarter. Dynavax had already tried and failed to win approval in 2013, but the company says that it's now addressed all the issues that the FDA raised at the time.Dynavax stock was up nearly 30% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 27.50.William Blair analyst Katherine Xu raised her price target on Dynavax stock to 45 from 42 while maintaining her outperform rating."We maintain our estimate for a Heplisav launch in the United States in third quarter 2016 in the full adult population, with $600 million in peak sales eight years into launch," Xu wrote in her research note. "We expect potential approval in Europe to occur in 2019 after post-marketing studies to expand the safety database."RBC Capital Markets analyst Simos Simeonidis was also positive on approval prospects but expressed slight concern about safety."(The) autoimmune debate/overhang (was) not completely put to rest," Simeonidis wrote in his research note. "There was an imbalance of new-onset autoimmune events in the trial: 8 in Heplisav arm vs. 1 in Engerix arm. Management mentioned that in the overall safety dataset, this imbalance is not there."Dynavax still isn't expected to turn a profit until 2018, as it does not have any other products out yet. The company is developing a cancer therapy as well as an asthma treatment in collaboration with AstraZeneca (AZN).Follow Amy Reeves on Twitter @IBD_Areeves and on Facebook.A fresh box of tools wasn't enough for retail supply-chain software developer SPS Commerce (SPSC) to quick-fix the downward dive of its stock this week. But Toronto-based ToolBox Solutions should provide SPS with enough analytics tools to grow revenue from grocery stores and pharmacies for years to come.Minneapolis-based SPS Commerce disclosed the $22.9 million purchase of ToolBox on Wednesday, before the market open, in the midst of the stock market tumble. It had closed 2015 last Thursday near 70, 10% off an Oct. 12 high. On the first trading day of 2016, it fell 3.4%, then 1.5% Tuesday. It closed down 3.2% Wednesday after its morning announcement.SPS Commerce stock was trading down nearly 2% as of early afternoon in the stock market today, although it had fallen more than 1% Thursday morning.Needham analyst Scott Berg said Thursday in a research note that the purchase price at 3.8 times ToolBox's estimated 2016 revenue is "in line for pure Software-as-a-Service-based software vendors that are marginally profitable."SPS said ToolBox may improve earnings by the first quarter of 2017. It said ToolBox should add about $1.45 million in sales in the current Q1 2016 but may take $300,000 off of adjusted earnings. For all of 2016, SPS said ToolBox should add $6 million in revenue and negatively impact adjusted EBITDA by about $800,000, as SPS absorbs $1.4 million in amortization expenses related to the purchase.SPS software serves about 60,000 customers in more than 60 countries throughout retailers' supply chains, including manufacturers, suppliers and distributors. Needham's Berg said: "The ToolBox analytics solutions are similar to SPSC's current Collaboration Analytics offering but add specific subvertical strength in grocery, convenience stores and pharmacy stores."Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect SPS to report earnings per share up 17% to 21 cents for Q4 when it releases 2015 performance Feb. 3, on revenue up 19% to $42.2 million. For the year, they expect EPS up 20% to 78 cents, on revenue up 24% to $158.4 million.A member of IBD's Computer Software-Specialty Enterprise industry group, SPS carries a $1.06 billion market cap, 5-1/2 years after going public, and an 81 IBD Composite Rating out of a possible 99. The biggest players in its industry group are VMware (VMW) with a market cap of $23 billion, CA (CA) with $11.7 billion and Citrix Systems (CTXS) with $10.9 billion.VMWare was trading down 3.3% in the early afternoon Thursday, CA was off 2.7% and Citrix down 4.5% as tech stocks and others widely slid in a market rout that followed another plunge in China stock trading.

ServiceNow's (NOW) push into new markets is expected to boost Q4 revenue, with analysts estimating sales growth of nearly 33%, with non-GAAP EPS rising 15%.The enterprise software provider reports fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday."Q4 represents the next leg of what we still see as a compelling second-half 2016 setup, with the easiest billings comparison of 2016 and estimates for quarter-over-quarter subscription revenue growth," said UBS analyst Brent Thill in a research report Tuesday.Analysts estimate Q4 revenue of $372 million and EPS minus items of 23 cents, up from 20 cents in the year earlier period. The 33% revenue growth is strong but the percentage continues to slip as the company gets bigger. That year-over-year growth is down from 37% in Q3, 38% in Q2 and 44% in Q1.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer-Software Enterprise group ranks No. 87 out of 197 industry groups. Paycom Software has the highest Composite Rating, an important metric in CAN SLIM investing. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, analysts project EPS ex items of 18 cents, doubling Q1 2016, and $403.2 million in revenue, up 32%. Analysts estimate full-year 2017 revenue of $1.8 billion, up 32%.ServiceNow's main competitors include CA, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), IBM (IBM) and Salesforce.com (CRM).ServiceNow stock fell 14% in 2016, but shares have moved above their 50-day moving average in January, with a buy point of 89.89. ServiceNow stock rose 0.9 to 83.97 in the stock market today.ServiceNow's core business is software for information technology service management, or ITSM. ServiceNow has expanded into human resources, customer service and security software.Billings growth stabilized after slowing in 2015, when the company reorganized sales."We continue to view ServiceNow as one of the select few in software to sustain 30%-plus subscription billings growth with free cash flow margins comfortably above 25% over the next years," said Keith Weiss, a Morgan Stanley analyst, in a report.RELATED:Salesforce.com Stock Rallies In 2017 As Top Software PickServiceNow Price Target Hits 100 On Earnings Beat

In most Presidential election years, the most important vote is the vote for President of the United States. This year, the most important vote looks like the vote for control of the Senate. Regardless of who wins the White House, the freedom that Americans have taken for granted -- taken too much for granted, for far too long -- can be destroyed by whomever the next President puts on the Supreme Court.Since the Senate has the power to approve or disapprove whatever nominee any President wants to put on the High Court, that makes the Senate this country's last line of defense against any headstrong President who puts his or her own power ahead of the freedom of more than 300 million Americans and of future generations.The Senate is also the last line of defense against any President who exceeds his or her own authority, and thereby destroys the Constitution's balance of power among the three branches of government that has kept this country free for more than two centuries.If either party -- whether Democrats or Republicans -- unites behind a President with no regard for the Constitution, that party can change the fundamental nature of American government, leaving not only the incumbent President, but future Presidents as well, able to rule virtually by decree.When the Democrats controlled both Houses of Congress, as well as the White House, we came dangerously close to that, with President Obama virtually repealing the immigration laws passed by Congress and issuing executive orders on this and other issues that simply took over the legislative power from Congress.Fortunately, there was still a third branch of government -- the federal judiciary -- which put a stop to some of these illegal actions. But, if that third branch of government is also taken over by one party, there is nothing left as a barrier against unbridled power.The Democrats are united behind Hillary Clinton in a way that the Republicans are by no means united behind Donald Trump. Mrs. Clinton also has overwhelming support by the media in a way that Mr. Trump never has and never will have.If either of these headstrong and self-centered individuals were to overstep the Constitutional boundaries as President of the United States, and endanger the freedom of Americans, only Donald Trump faces any real danger of being impeached by the House of Representatives and then being removed from office by the Senate.This is not to predict that either of them will in fact be impeached by the House and removed by the Senate. But penalties exist in the law not just to punish people, but to deter them from doing things that the penalties are there to prevent.Trump would be on a shorter leash, even if the Republicans controlled the Senate. And there is no way that he doesn't know that fact, with some Republicans already refusing to endorse his candidacy and some even announcing that they plan to vote for Hillary Clinton.But, with the Democrats controlling the Senate, Mrs. Clinton would know that she had a blank check, instead of a Constitutional check on her powers. With the Senate and the media on her side, there would be virtually nothing she could not get away with.Control of the Senate matters hugely, no matter who gets into the White House. It matters for the future of the Supreme Court, on which the rule of law depends, and it matters for keeping any President from running this country like a banana republic.The politically divided government, which the media so often and so loudly lament, may be all that can keep the next four years from being the last four years for Constitutional government and the freedom that depends on it.Republican control of the Senate is a necessary, but by no means sufficient, precondition for keeping a headstrong President within bounds. There are still painful memories of the preemptive surrender when Senator Lindsey Graham announced that he was going to vote to confirm Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court, even before she had been examined by the Senate.Regardless of who wins the White House or the Senate, the voters are going to have to keep their feet to the fire, to make sure that Senators do not simply take the path of least resistance. That path usually leads downhill, sometimes very far downhill.Thomas Sowell is a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, Stanford University, Stanford, CA

CyberArk Software's (CYBR) focus on "privileged access management" (PAM) puts the security provider in a good position amid trends in cyberattacks, says Pacific Crest Securities, which initiated coverage of the Israel-based firm with a sector weight rating based on valuation.Guggenheim Securities, meanwhile, initiated coverage on security software maker Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) with a neutral rating.Hackers often aim to compromise networks by targeting employees or management with administrative access to company computer systems."CyberArk's technology protects, monitors and manages privileged accounts, which are the cornerstones of exploitation in today's megahacks," said Rob Owen, a Pacific Crest analyst, in a research report.Yet, he said that "with lofty expectations reflected in its valuation, we would look to get more constructive on a valuation reset or further evidence of an inflection in TAM (total addressable market. ... with CyberArk trading on par with companies like Palo Alto Networks (PANW) that exhibit higher revenue growth expectations, greater revenue visibility and similar margins, it appears the market is optimistically contemplating both the significant PAM opportunity that lies beyond the forecast horizon and CyberArk's potential to drive significant operating leverage through its growth arc."IBD'S TAKE: Valuations of many software security firms are down from a year ago, leading some analysts to speculation that M&A may pick up. IBD's Software Security group is ranked No. 22 out of 197 industry groups. CyberArk is a leader of the group,and is currently on the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks.CyberArk competes in the PAM market with privately held Dell Technologies, CA Technologies (CA), BeyondTrust and Lieberman Software."We are positive on CyberArk's fundamentals, given its differentiated solution set, significant market opportunity, demonstrated operating leverage and market penetration momentum," added Owen. "We would look to become more constructive following a valuation pullback or evidence that lends higher confidence to the prospect of broader market adoption."CyberArk stock, which touched a 13-month high of 59.28 on Sept. 7, fell 1.6% to 50.87 in the stock market today. Check Point stock rose 0.6% to 75.51 but is still close to a near-eight-month low of 74.38 set on Aug. 10.RELATED:FireEye A More Likely Seller As Founder Departs?Sharks Eye Appetizing Multiples In SaaS Software Deals

If investors got everything they wanted from Citrix Systems' (CTXS) decision to spin off the GoTo family of businesses, why did Citrix stock fall like a dead weight Wednesday morning?Perhaps because analysts can see more clearly now the work and time still required to achieve their goals.Shares tumbled 8% after the morning bell in the stock market today, after the CEO late Tuesday announced that Citrix would spin off its GoTo family of businesses into its own publicly traded corporation, designed as a tax-free deal for investors, unlike an outright sale might have been.Citrix is a leading enabler of the migration to cloud computing by selling software as a service.Citrix is "on the right track, but the path is still uphill," wrote Pacific Crest Securities analyst Rob Owens in a research note issued after the disclosures."Overall, we view management's operational announcements as necessary for the future of the business, but see increased near-term execution risk and continued lackluster growth. We remain on the sidelines."Owens reiterated a "sector weight" rating without a price target.Shares were trading down 9% at 71.32 by early afternoon, about 14% off a three-year high near 84 set Oct. 28.With a healthy Composite Rating of 91, Citrix is a member of IBD's Computer Software-Specialty Enterprise industry group, third in market capitalization behind VMware (VM) and CA (CA). VMware market value is about $24 billion with CA at about half that size. Citrix's market value stands at $10.9 billion.The uphill path will require the layoff of about 1,000 employees and contractors outside the GoTo family separation — that is happening this month and in January, Citrix said — and the reduction of other Citrix operating expenses by $200 million in the next 18 months, most of which will occur in 2016.Also, "to achieve this focus (on Citrix's core software virtualization businesses), the company will end investment in certain other products and programs, in some cases moving technologies into strategic products, in other cases providing an orderly end-of-life to noncore products," the company said."The evaluation of all products, technologies, offerings and programs is ongoing, and will focus on enterprise readiness, ability to drive customer value, and growth and profitability prospects."The surviving Citrix, with roughly $2.6 billion in sales, will include the application virtualization, network management and performance management software businesses handling XenApp, XenDesktop, XenMobile, ShareFile and NetScaler products.The spinoff will be composed of GoToAssist, GoToMeeting, GoToMyPC, GoToTraining, GoToWebinar, Grasshopper and OpenVoice, products with combined sales of about $600 million for the 12 months that ended Sept. 30, the company said.The company plans to fold underlying Bytemobile technologies into the NetScaler platform, while winding down Bytemobile, Podio and WorkspacePod.Currently, Citrix is "too broad and complex," Bob Calderoni, the interim CEO of Citrix, told analysts after Tuesday's announcement. Calderoni succeeded 14-year CEO Mark Templeton in July. He'd been under pressure from activist investor Elliott Management.Immediately following the separation, Citrix shareholders will own shares in two publicly traded companies.Citrix has been studying the reorganization since midyear and has retained Goldman Sachs and Qatalyst Partners as financial advisers."Upon review, it is clear to us that the GoTo family of products is best suited to grow and operate as a stand-alone business," said Calderoni in the announcement. "This separation will create a leading, pure-play SaaS (software-as-a-service) company that will have a targeted focus with the flexibility to invest in its portfolio of products."It will also allow Citrix to refocus and amplify investment in our core mission to enable secure and reliable delivery of apps and data for the modern enterprise. We look forward to a seamless transition for our employees, customers, partners and other key stakeholders."Chris Hylen, senior vice president and general manager of the Citrix Mobility Apps business unit, will serve as CEO of the spinoff company. Calderoni said that a CEO for Citrix will be announced "in the not too distant future." Candidates are being vetted currently.After the announcement, responding to a securities analyst who wondered if the new CEO would be hamstrung by being required to spin off the GoTo family, Calderoni said his successor's job would be easier."The worst CEO job to have is to be the head of a company that is spread too wide and too thin," said Calderoni. "We're setting up the company very well. It will be focused, and it'll be profitable . .. . Investment dollars are hard to find when you're trying to feed too many things."Bhavan Suri, a William Blair analyst, anticipated the spinoff in a research note last week."We estimate the GoTo assets to contribute approximately 57 cents EPS in 2016 (assuming 6.5% sales growth and 18% operating margin on a stand-alone basis)," Suri wrote. "This would result in an implied stock price of $14.26 and is based on a forward-looking price-to-earnings ratio of 25 times, which we believe is reasonable, given that we suspect the company could not find a buyer for the segment (excluding ShareFile) at 4.5 times 2016 revenue."The software maker said in July that it expects full-year adjusted earnings of $3.65 to $3.75 a share, where analysts had modeled $3.56.Acknowledging the "disruption" that spinning off GoTo products will cause, Citrix is now guiding net revenue growth of 1% to 2%, an adjusted operating margin "of at least 28%," and adjusted earnings of $4.40 to $4.50 per share for the fiscal year ending Dec. 31, 2016.For the current fiscal 2015, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters anticipate adjusted EPS of $3.88 on revenue of $3.25 billion, with revenue increasing to $3.4 billion in 2016. The company says that 2017 revenue likely will grow 4% to 5%; the company is targeting an adjusted operating margin of "at least" 30% by then."Citrix is still a very relevant IT player," said FBR analyst Daniel Ives in a research note, "and now it all comes down to leveraging that position into tangential growth opportunities within the data center and cloud computing shift, with all eyes on rekindling growth on its core desktop/cloud franchise. We maintain our outperform rating."Citrix peer VMWare's stock was down 2.6% in early afternoon trade Wednesday. CA Technologies was up 3.9% on a dividend increase and increased share buyback program.

Stocks managed to close higher yesterday...but was that just a 'flash in the pan'?  Traders shrugged off more weakness in crude oil,  Energy names actually rallied a bit, as the mkt continues to try and find its 'chi'...... What is 'chi'?  Well - it is the way so many Asian's find their 'flow of life, their breath, their energy...basically moving with chi - is being in a relaxed and free flowing state.'And while I do not believe that the mkts can really find their chi while oil is still under pressure and future FED policy remains anyone's guess........yesterday's bounce was a welcomed event.  And so the hunt is on....traders and investors all trying to find their chi as we move into year end and what is clearly expected to be the first interest rate hike in 6 yrs (the odds now put a hike at 87%) ..... Perhaps yesterday's small gains were nothing more than a knee jerk bounce following the stronger moves lower last week and in the early part of this week. And I said this yesterday morning.....stocks had become a bit oversold and were due for a small bounce...and that is what we got - BUT this morning US futures are pointing significantly lower - currently down 14 pts as we prepare for a slew of US macro data reports..........Overnight global mkts didn't perform much better......as none of them at the moment seem to be able to find their Chi either. Bargain hunting may have been the theme yesterday.....but as the countdown to next Wednesday continues - the tone is decidedly bearish......Emerging mkt countries getting whacked, European stocks at 2 month lows, and oil - down 14% since December  1st - is headed for its worst week since the summer.Yesterday's  bounce, though welcomed, was only a diversion from the range of concerns that we have been talking about for months now.... - But the overriding theme continues to be the oil story and the FED story....and  until we see oil stabilize, stocks will continue to struggle.  I mean what we really need to see is for stocks to decouple from oil and from every single word that the FED speaks........but that does not look like it's going to happen just yet......After all that is said - guess what - we are still range bound (2030/2100) ......the S&P has to find support at 2030 today (100 dma) for that to remain true... a break here will open the flood gates....the mkt will test 2000 on the S&P quickly - but that is only a psychological level....there is no real support there at all.....keep your eyes focused on the 1950/1975 range as the next real stop in terms of where we might find support if we break. I mean look - the mkt is trying to move past both the oil story and the FED story.....but the nervousness over what the future looks like is clear...in the past week the VIX (Fear Index) has shot up 30%  - suggesting that investors/traders remain anxious over FED policy and the real state of the economy.  As much as we think the mkt has discounted the coming rate hike (and I think it has as well) investors/traders remain skeptical about FUTURE rate hikes and FED policy.  So - All eyes are laser focused the Fed’s FOMC meeting next week.... 95% of business and academic economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal agree that the Fed will raise the benchmark rate on Wednesday and on average participants estimated that the probability now stands at 87%, up from 71% last month.   In fact 82% of economists surveyed said they thought the Fed’s credibility would be damaged if it didn’t raise rates next week.  And why?  Because they have painted themselves into a corner... insisting, banging on the table that the time was right......Look - THEY have created this monster....with their wishy washy stance all year long....Today we get a slew of US eco data - data that will provide one last peek at the state of the economy and the consumer before the final bell tolls...........and this morning the mkt is suggesting that we may be disappointed......At 8:30 we will get Retail Sales - exp of +0.3%, ex autos and gas of +0.4%.....PPI - Producer Price Index - is exp to show 0% move.....ex food and energy is expected to be +0.1%, while PPI final demand year over year is expected to be negative 1.4%.   But on the brighter side - the U of Mich Sentiment Index is expected to rise to 92.  (Of course it will...) because the consumer is feeling so good about the current state of affairs....I will be speaking at the Investor's Business Daily -  Level 4 - Master's Program  on Saturday, December 12th at the Fairmont Miramar Hotel in Santa Monica, CA.  "Evolution of the US Capital Markets - 1980 - 2015"   It is a overview of what was, what is and how we got here. It is full of history and details the very exciting  journey over the past 35 years that took us from the centralized open outcry auction  market to the 21st century automated, fractured, fragmented marketplace that we now call the US capital markets.  Beginning from the birth of the greatest bull market and taking us thru the crash of '87, the advancements of technology, the .com bubble, decimalization, 911, modernization, fragmentation and HFT.     I hope to see you there.    My next note will be Tuesday, December 15th.  Take good care - KpKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Investing in fixed-income mutual funds rewarded investors with annual returns of 5% to 10% over the past 10 years in an environment of low interest rates. Which bond funds got the winning ticket and how did they get there?The IBD Best Mutual Funds 2016 Awards include U.S. taxable bond, municipal bond and foreign bond funds that have at least $100 million in assets and beat their benchmark index for all four performance periods studied: one year, three years, five years and 10 years.In the U.S. taxable bond universe, top-performing funds are Pimco Fixed Income Shares C (FXICX), TCW Total Return Bond I (TGLMX) and American Century Zero Coupon 2025 Inv (BTTRX) with average 10-year performance of 10.20%, 6.82% and 6.62%, respectively.Click Here To View The Top Performing Funds By CategoryPimco's $1.5 billion fund invests at least 80% of its net assets into U.S. government and corporate debt, but also holds small allocations in non-U.S. debt. In addition, it has about 9% in securitized bonds, such as agency and nonagency residential as well as commercial mortgages. Management was not available for comment.TCW's $9.5 billion fund has benefited from a strong recovery in mortgages since the credit crisis. Over 70% of the fund is in securitized debt, including 35% in agency and 12% in nonagency residential mortgage-backed securities, as well as a 9% allocation in commercial MBS and 14% in asset-backed securities.TCW fund manager Bryan Whalen points to three main drivers behind the mutual fund's solid relative performance last year. First, there was "almost no exposure to the corporate credit market." The performance of that market relative to similar-duration Treasuries was -161 basis points, or 1.61%, whereas almost 50% of the fund was in agency mortgages and the excess returns in that sector relative to Treasuries was only -5 basis points or -0.05%, explained Whalen, who's been on board the fund since 2009."So the exceptional outperformance of mortgages relative to investment-grade corporate bonds was one driver," Whalen said. "The second one was: where we were taking on more credit risk, we were doing it in what in hindsight turned out to be the best place to place your credit chips last year, which was nonagency mortgage-backed securities. . . That sector was up over 3% last year. . . and it was roughly 25% of the fund in 2015."The third contributor to the fund’s outperformance was its slight underweight in duration vs. the index. "Interest rates last year rose by about 25 bps and this fund had about a year less duration than the index and so that was a benefit as well," said Whalen.In the nontaxable universe, the top-performing municipal bond fund was Ivy Municipal High Income I (WYMHX) with an average 10-year return of 5.6%. Over shorter periods of time, several California muni funds did well, including Franklin CA High Yield Municipal A (FCAMX), Nuveen CA Municipal Bond I (NCSPX) and Northern CA Tax-Exempt (NCATX) scoring five-year average returns of 8.59%, 8.06% and 7.50%, respectively.Ivy Funds fund manager Michael Walls explained that in addition to providing high levels of tax-exempt income to investors, the fund also strives to limit volatility. To do so, managers try to focus on the credit cycles: "If you look back to '06, '07 and the beginning of '08, we didn’t feel like we were getting adequately compensated for risk." So they deployed some money into one-off trades but kept liquidity high to exploit a potential credit-widening event. As a result, the fund underperformed in '06 and '07, but was able to take advantage of market opportunities in the second half of '08."We were defensive. I had the duration of the product at just over five years, which was about 50% short the benchmark and we were higher quality," said Walls. "So we ended up having extremely good performance . . . when other funds had considerable outflows, we had liquidity to reinvest in projects, for example health care."The $1.4 billion fund currently has an underweight in health care and an overweight in transportation and education revenue bonds. It yields 4.3% and charges a 0.68% fee.In the foreign bond category, only two funds made the cut of having at least $100 million in assets and beating their benchmarks in each of the past 1, 3, 5 and 10 years: Pimco Foreign Bond (USD Hedged) I (PFORX) and Consulting Group International Fund I (TIFUX). They each returned 6.14% and 4.90% over the past 10 years, respectively.Pimco's $7.7 billion fund invests the bulk of its assets in government debt of the eurozone and Japan. London-based CIO global fixed income Andrew Balls took over the fund in 2014, bringing global fixed-income market expertise with him."Management shifts the regional weight quite a lot, including over short periods," said senior manager research analyst Mara Dobrescu of Morningstar. For example, last year, the manager increased the fund's stake in Japan from 20% in 2014 to 37% in 2015, "because he basically found that the longer-dated Japanese government and agency debt was really more attractive than the similar European issues."The fund also doesn't shy away from investing in emerging market bonds. "In early 2015, the team significantly reduced the fund's stake in Brazil due to a lack of clarity following the election. They have generally stayed out of Russia as risks were deemed too high in the context of pressure on commodity prices. However, the manager kept a position on Mexico, where he sees still-solid growth and benefits from the country's trade ties with the U.S., with a preference for local Mexican debt over external debt," she said.Major contributors to performance last year were its overweight in Spanish and Italian government bonds. It also had a small foreign currency overlay, including some short positions on the euro, Japanese yen and some Asian currencies, she explained. In addition, the fund’s 0.50% fee is below its peers.

CyberArk Software (CYBR) garnered another buyout prediction Wednesday, as Summit Redstone relaunched coverage with a buy rating on CyberArk stock, saying its double-digit growth trajectory makes it a "compelling" acquisition candidate.Summit analyst Srini Nandury expects the information security company to continue to gain from the high-profile breaches of Home Depot (HD) and Target (TGT), and the whistleblower cases involving Chelsea Manning (formerly Bradley Manning) and Edward Snowden, because of the niche that CyberArk fills in privileged account security."Unlike other parts of the security landscape, privileged account security (PAS) still remains a greenfield opportunity given that businesses have under-invested for a long time, leaving their critical infrastructure vulnerable," Nandury wrote in a research report.CyberArk has near-term and first-mover advantages, but could see rivalry from Exceedium (acquired last year by CA (CA)), Lieberman Software, Centrify and BalaBit.Total addressable market estimates range from $2 billion to $10 billion, Nandury wrote.CyberArk is "profitable and prolifically cash-generating," making it a rarity among rivals, he wrote. Over the past six quarters, CyberArk beats sales views by 20% and EPS views by even more, he said."We expect the beats and raises to continue, driven by elevated spending and increased sales capacity," Nandury wrote.He has a 55 price target on CyberArk stock, which rose 2.3% to 46.54 on the stock market today.

Gene-sequencing giant Illumina (ILMN) pre-announced Q3 revenue and full-year guidance that missed estimates Monday, sending its stock tumbling after hours.Illumina said Q3 revenue totaled $550 million, up 14% from the year-earlier quarter but $19 million short of analysts' consensus, according to Thomson Reuters. The company also said it expects Q4 revenue of $570 million, up 11% from last year but $32 million shy of Wall Street's estimate.That adds up to 18% sales growth for the year, vs. analysts' expectations of 21% growth. The company will report final Q3 results on Oct. 20."Demand for sequencing consumables and the HiSeq family of instruments remained strong during the quarter, while instrument sales in the desktop family underperformed our expectations," Illumina CEO Jay Flatley said in a statement. "Geographically, we were disappointed with instrument sales in Europe and continued weakness in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite this 3% shortfall to expectations, our competitive position and product development pipeline are as strong as ever."The announcement continued a recent stretch of bad news for Illumina, starting with its surprise Q2 revenue miss after a long record of beating estimates. Last week, the stock also suffered after Leerink analyst Dan Leonard downgraded it, writing that he saw the current product cycle as being lighter on upgrades and replacements than previous cycles. The unexpectedly early launch of a competing gene-sequencing product from Pacific Biosciences (PACB) also has weighed on shares."We had been cautioning for some time that 3Q/4Q estimates looked aggressive and thus today's negative pre-announcement does not come as a massive surprise," wrote Evercore ISI analyst Ross Muken in an email to clients. "The key question for us remains what helps to re-accelerate instrument growth (key driver of multiple) and what will the company offer at JPM (the JPMorgan Healthcare Conference) in a few months of time to swing sentiment. With modest competition also entering the market we expect the uncertainty to keep shares range bound at depressed levels and we await further clarity prior to revisiting our thesis."Illumina's stock was thus already down 32% from its July 20 high when it closed down a fraction at 163.50 in regular trade Monday. An hour after the close, it was down 13% to about 142. Pacific Biosciences was down about 5% after hours, perhaps on the assumption of overall weakness in the sequencing market.Illumina still holds an excellent EPS Rank of 98, but a Relative Strength Rating of only 35.Follow Amy Reeves on Twitter @IBD_Areeves and on Facebook.

The No. 1 provider of Linux open-source operating system software reported earnings per share minus items of 47 cents, up 14.6% from the year-earlier period and 3 cents above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.

Revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 31 rose 13% to $504 million, where analysts had modeled $494.7 million.Red Hat (RHT) said it expects fiscal 2016 EPS excluding items of $1.85 to $1.87, vs. the $1.83 expected by analysts. The company forecasts revenue of $2.03 billion to $2.04 billion, ahead of views. At the midpoints, EPS would be up 12% and sales up nearly 14%.

"Despite currency headwinds, the company exceeded expectations," Al Hilwa, an analyst with tech research firm IDC, told IBD. "What is really impressive is the synergy they are getting out of their (application development) and operating system business through cross deals.

"The growth in the (application development) subscription business, at 48%, is really hitting it out of the ballpark compared to how the rest of the industry is doing in this space. That this segment has now reached 16% of Red Hat's business drives the point home that they are not just an operating systems company."
Red Hat stock, though, was down 1% in after-hours trading, after the company released its results, after at first seesawing between slightly up and slightly down.
The company is making strides in making many of its applications cloud-based, Red Hat CEO Jim Whitehurst said in the company's earnings release.
Up 21% In Constant Currency

"Strong execution in Q2 contributed to total revenue results that exceeded 21% year-over-year growth on a constant currency basis. We were pleased with the progress of our technologies that address cloud deployments across multiple footprints," Whitehurst said in the release. "We are also thrilled to be the first open-source company to achieve an annualized run-rate of $2 billion in revenue this quarter.
"In addition, we believe Red Hat is well-positioned for the second half of the fiscal year as we continue to benefit from delivering innovation to our customers."

The leader in Linux systems hit a 15-year, post-dot-com-boom high of 81.49 when it reported Q1 earnings in June, but shares fell as much as 18% from that high this month when the market retreated. Red Hat stock rose 2.3% in Monday's regular session, to 72.72.
Red Hat's all-time high, adjusted for stock splits, is 151.31, reached in December 1999, at the height of the dot-com craze.
Red Hat's competitors include Oracle (ORCL) and Intel's (INTC) Wind River Systems, as well as Symantec (SYMC), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), CA (CA) and Citrix Systems (CTXS).
Red Hat has been getting mixed reviews of late, as the company looks beyond Linux to the cloud and other areas for growth.
The company has received two price-target hikes in the last quarter, and had one investment firm initiate coverage with a buy rating, according to 24/7 Wall St.

But stock analysis firm ValuEngine on Monday said in a research report that it expects Red Hat's earnings to lag its sector's growth over the next year. Compared with Check Point, Symantec, CA and Citrix, it will rank last in return on investment over the next year, said ValuEngine.
But Red Hat will outpace both its sector and the S&P 500 over the next five years, the report says.

Researcher firm New Constructs called for investors to sell Red Hat shares, in a report issued over the weekend, giving Red Hat stock its second-lowest "dangerous" rating. The research firm says Red Hat's levels of price-to-economic-book-value and growth appreciation are considered to be "very dangerous," but it also said its free-cash-flow yield is "attractive."The No. 1 provider of Linux open-source operating system software reported earnings per share minus items of 47 cents, up 14.6% from the year-earlier period and 3 cents above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 31 rose 13% to $504 million, where analysts had modeled $494.7 million.Red Hat (RHT) said it expects fiscal 2016 EPS excluding items of $1.85 to $1.87, vs. the $1.83 expected by analysts. Former federal prosecutor Joseph DiGenova stirred the Hillary Clinton hornets' nest Tuesday when he said on talk radio that he is convinced "she's not going to be able to complete her campaign" because "she's going to have to be charged with a crime.""Her biggest problem right now is the FBI. They're not going away," DiGenova said on the "Laura Ingraham Show." "They have reached a critical mass in their investigation of the secretary and all of her senior staff. And it's going to come to a head, I would suggest, in the next 60 days. And I predict Hillary will not make it to the finish line."DiGenova said that investigators have found more than 1,200 classified emails from the private Clinton account, and he indicated that they are likely to recover more from her hard drive. The evidence that the FBI is finding against her is so compelling that Attorney General Loretta Lynch will have no choice but to charge Clinton, he believes. If Lynch resists, "there will be a massive revolt inside the FBI, which she will not be able to survive as an attorney general. It will be like Watergate."So overwhelming is the evidence, explains DiGenova, that if there's no indictment, the FBI "will never be able to charge another federal employee with the negligent handling of classified information. The intelligence community will not stand for that. They will fight for indictment."The only way to know if DiGenova's comments are grounded on strong inside sources, or if he's speculating based on his experience and observations, is to wait. But he does add an interesting component to the campaign: What if Clinton is indeed indicted in two months? What happens to her campaign? Does she stay on the trail? Or does she suspend the campaign while justice plays out?We can safely say she won't plead guilty. She's a Clinton. They don't do that. Accepting blame and admitting guilt isn't in their political handbook.The possibility that Clinton is nominated by the Democrats and then elected by the voters in November, all the while awaiting a court date, is troubling. Would her party still nominate her, and would a simple majority of voters pull the lever for her, after she had been charged? It's frightening to know that in today's America we cannot categorically rule out these scenarios. The electorate, as the past two presidential elections and the rabid support for Donald Trump have shown, has lost its mind.For his part, DiGenova believes that Clinton is "not going to be able to complete her campaign." If she's charged, dropping out is the most agreeable outcome. There are a lot of us who don't want to see the White House operating out of the female federal corrections institution in Dublin, Ca., for eight years.Follow Kerry Jackson on Twitter @IBD_KJackson.

Better-than-expected results couldn't help Red Hat (RHT) stock Tuesday, with shares of the enterprise software company succumbing to concerns over billing as well as a sharp market downturn.

Red Hat shares were trading down almost 2% to near 72 in the stock market today, virtually wiping out gains from the prior day. Investors had bid up shares Monday ahead of the after-hours earnings report.

Some analysts attributed the losses to the market's general downturn. The Nasdaq was down about 2%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell more than 1.5% as they approached midday trading.

But it wasn't just that, some said, as Red Hat also disappointed with its billing numbers. Oppenheimer's Brian Schwartz noted that although currency changes affected valuations by 8%, billing growth of 9% still fell short of expectations.
"Billings (at) 9% is not enough to excite investors and it is the slowest growth for them in eight quarters with tougher year-to-year billings comparisons lying ahead," Schwartz said.

On Monday, Red Hat reported second-quarter earnings of 47 cents a share, up 15% from a year ago and 3 cents ahead of forecasts from analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 13% to $504 million, ahead of views for $494.7 million.

The maker of open-source Linux operating systems also predicted full-year earnings and revenue that were ahead of estimates. Red Hat expects fiscal 2016 earnings of $1.85 to $1.87 a share, up from the $1.83 forecast and 12% ahead of 2015 at the midpoint. Sales are also expected to reach $2.03 billion to $2.04 billion, slightly ahead of views and up 14% from 2015 at the midpoint.
While Schwartz was concerned about billing figures for Red Hat, other analysts said it may not be worth worrying about.

"Billings fell short of consensus expectations but Street modeling has been inconsistent here and billings were impacted by currency and lower contract duration, issues that will likely reverse going forward," BTIG analyst Joel P. Fishbein said in a note to clients. "Overall, we believe Red Hat is one of the best-positioned infrastructure providers in software, with strong execution, a product portfolio that is well-aligned with prevailing technology trends, solid and consistent growth, and continued operating leverage."
Jason Ader, an analyst at William Blair, echoed a similar tone in his research note to clients.
"Red Hat looks optimally positioned to take advantage of the larger trend toward enterprise adoption of open source software and hybrid cloud technology, in our view," Ader wrote.
Red Hat's rivals include Oracle (ORCL), Intel's (INTC) Wind River Systems, Symantec (SYMC), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), CA (CA) and Citrix Systems (CTXS).
